captions.text:
Know your limits and work up to them, speed
is not inherently unsafe but overconfidence

and panic are. Check your breaks before you
descend, if i'm descending on a straight road

I put more emphasis on my front brake over
my back brake to slow down, it's more effective.

If it's wet or an extremely steep descent
I also use my front break. Use your back break

over your front break when you're turning.
Ideally though you should start turning at

the correct speed to get around the corner
not break once you're in the corner. This

is up to you and what makes you feel most
comfortable, generally there are 2 main positions,on

the hoods of the handle bars or the drops,
riding on the drops is safer as it allows

for a better grip and faster descent. Some
of the pros adopt a third position, almost

a tuck position when balanced on the top tube,
move your weight over the rear wheel slightly

when breaking hard to prevent the rear wheel
locking up and to make sure you don't go head

first over the bars. Look ahead, as you're
approaching a corner look past the corner

almost an exaggerated peer and stay on the
correct side of the white line. This will

achieve 2 things; 1 keep your balance and
focus and 2 prevent you getting run over by

ascending vehicles. Don't cross over the white
dash line in the road, if there are hairpin

bends take these wide so you can maintain
as much control as possible. Position your

outside pedal at the 6 o clock position and
push the weight through this pedal, this will

give you more grip. If you're concerned about
balance counteract this with your inside knee

directing it away from the bike towards the
ground. This is really important, relax your

shoulders, look ahead not at the ground and
don't fight the bike. The more relaxed you

are going into a corner the easier it will
feel, let the bike do the work. Be careful

of other riders on the road you might be in
control of your bike but you can't control

other riders, keep an eye out for your fellow
racers if you're not confident in those around

you leave them plenty of room in case they
make a sudden, risky manoeuvre. For more videos
like this go to www.youtube.com/gcn

comments.text:
Good for you! I know they teach that, but it is an unnecessary thing to 
stress. It's only going to confuse. Ask a student to negotiate different 
radii corners and they will use different initial degrees of countersteer. 
Ask them to decrease the radius of their turn mid-corner and they will 
naturally apply the correct steering input. To believe that it is possible 
to ride a bike without countersteering is some sort of psychosis.
comments.author: jp3d2k

comments.text:
You are way overthinking this! A bike is a self-stabilizing system, and it 
is very intuitive to control one by practicing, but very complex to explain 
how that control is actually achieved. If you tell them about countersteer 
should you also go into detail about how camber thrust and steering slip 
angle work together to balance the forces of a bike accelerating around a 
corner? Maybe, but these are not things that you need to know, and 
certainly not things to keep in your mind with practicing.
comments.author: jp3d2k

comments.text:
Steering a two-wheeled vehicle has basci components AND understanding 
counter-steering is crucial to control. lack of control is what is the 
primary causation of accidents. Not road surface, not conditions, not 
anything else (as these are examples of secondary causations) but loss of 
control of the elements of bike handling, due to a rider not understanding 
what he or she is doing or not doing. Thinking that your 'muscle memory' is 
going to save you from a potential accident is foolish.
comments.author: Projekt Archetype - X

want to go" the countersteering is simply subconscious muscle memory.
